all_paragraphs: When we want to access a part of a sequence such as a string, tuple or list, we can leverage a feature in Python known as slicing which enables us to write much cleaner, concise and readable code.
Slicing may be used to view, modify or delete items from sequences that are mutable such as in a list data type. Additionally, this feature also leverages well with frameworks like NumPy and Pandas.

Slicing an array is not much different to slicing a list. The main differences is that arrays you can slice an array in more than one dimension and another important factor I will speak on next.
Similar to what I mentioned in the previous PyTrix Series on indexing;

when we take a slice of an array, the returned array is a view of the original array — we have ultimately accessed the same data in a different order. Whereas, when we slice a list it will return a completely new list.
To show you how Python’s built in slicing feature works, I will now demonstrate its functionality…
Next, I will demonstrate how python slicing works and take a slice of this list and print it…
When we use slice notation, we are specifying the [start:end] index’s that we want from our slice. This copies the list from the start up too, but not including the end index.

A cool thing that we can also do is to omit the start or the end from the slice. For instance, if we omit the start and provide an index to end at, Python would slice from the beginning index up to but not including the index provided at the end. Alternatively, if we omit the end and supply a start, Python would start from the start index provided and slice to the end of the list. See the code cell below for an example.
Notice that in list e I did not supply a start or end. This is simply a copy of the entire list.
Finally, just so that we do not complicate this with indexing. Let’s see the difference between a list and a slice.
The index returns an element of the list at the given index, whereas the slice returns a list of a single element.
As mentioned, slicing 1D Numpy arrays and list are almost the same task, nonetheless, there is a distinct property that distinguishes them as you’ll see.

The distinguishing property is that unlike in a list which creates a new list when sliced, NumPy slices return a view of the data that we have stored in np_b . Therefore, if we are to change an element in np_b then this will also change in np_a — and vice versa. Look at the next code cell for an example:
2D arrays can be sliced across both axes…
To break this down, we have taken the rows from 1: to the end of the array and columns 1:3 (therefore columns 1 and 2).
3D Arrays can be sliced in all 3 axes…

We selected all of the planes starting from index 1, all of the rows starting from index 1 and all of the columns. For clarity reasons, since this can be quite tricky, I have explained this again below;

In all honesty, it wasn’t necessary that I included the : for the columns. We can obtain full slices of planes, rows or columns using the : feature. However, when we have trailing indices, we can still obtain a full slice by simply omitting the index.
